title: About
text:
Hello! My name is Terachet (Drive) Rojrachsombat, and I am a graduate student at Stanford University pursuing a Master of Science in Earth Systems with a focus on Climate Science and Climate Change. My passion lies in understanding and addressing climate change through scientific research, education, and communication.




Master of Science in Earth Systems Science
Stanford University (2024 – Present)

Focus: Physics and Chemistry of Climate

Thesis: Atmospheric Composition Controls on the Monsoon System

Bachelor of Science in Earth Systems
Stanford University (2019 – 2024)

Track: Oceans, Atmosphere, and Climate








Research Assistant (Sep. 2023 – Present)
- Investigated the impact of aerosol and GHG forcings on the global monsoon system.
- Employed NCAR’s LENS2 model experiments to isolate the effects of individual forcings.
- Findings suggest intensification of the Asian Summer Monsoon until 2060 due to greenhouse gas forcing.



Research Assistant (Jun. – Sep. 2023)
- Analyzed rainfall and political outcomes in Sub-Saharan Africa using CHIRPS and conflict datasets.
- Identified connections between rainfall variability and political violence through causal inference methods.



Carbon System Researcher (Apr. – Sep. 2022)
- Conducted an inorganic carbon survey during SEA Cruise S-303.
- Linked intermediate-depth pH decreases to La Niña events and water mass tracers.



Research Assistant (Jun. – Sep. 2020)
- Evaluated biases in CMIP6 models of the North American Monsoon.
- Found that global warming scenarios consistently weaken monsoon systems.







ESS246A/CEE261I: Atmosphere, Ocean, and Climate Dynamics (Sep. 2024 – Present)
- Supported students with assignments, labs, and atmospheric analysis techniques.
- Delivered lectures and guided lab demonstrations with rotating tank experiments.



Earth Systems Department, Stanford University (Sep. 2023 – Jun. 2024)
- Advised students on academic planning, including course tracks and four-year plans.
- Organized events to foster community engagement within the Earth Systems program.



(Jan. 2017 – Jan. 2022)
- Trained and mentored Thai students, leading to international medal wins.
- Designed field excursions and practice exams for advanced geography topics.






Outstanding Service to the Earth Systems Program – Stanford University (2024)

Dean’s Award for Undergraduate Academic Achievement – Stanford University (2023)

Sustainability Research Grant – Stanford Earth ($7,500, 2023)

Stanford Earth Summer Undergraduate Research Grant – ($7,500, 2020)
National Student Award – Thailand’s highest academic honor (2018)

Gold Medal – International Geography Olympiad (2017)






Climate Models: CMIP6, CMIP5, CESM2, ScenarioMIPs, AerChemMIP, AMIP, Single-Forcing Models

Reanalysis and Satellite Data: NOAA/CIRES/DOE, NCEP, NCAR, GHCN, COBE, CHIRPS, CMAP, GPCC

Weather Analysis: GFS, ECMWF, NAM, LogP-SkewT, Weather Radar, Doppler Radar, Weather Stations

R Programming: Geospatial R, Package Development, Quarto, Rcpp, HTML, terra, raster, ncf4, ggplot2

Other Programming: Git, Python, MATLAB, Jupyter, High-Performance Computing

Technical Writing: Package documentation, academic papers, Quarto websites

Public Speaking: Lecturing, tutoring, advising, science communication, media outreach

Leadership: Research collaborations, activism experience, military leadership experience






Stanford Marching Band (LSJUMB) – Staff, Member, and Arranger of various scores (2022 – Present)

Community Emergency Response Team (CERT) – Volunteer First Responder (2022 – Present)

Pro-Democracy Student Movement (Thailand) – Active Coordinator and Participant (2020 – 2021)
Climate Strike Thailand Student Movement – Active Organizer and Participant (2019 – 2021)

Fossil Free Stanford at Stanford University – Active Organizer and Member (2019 – 2020)

Thai Student Association at Stanford University – Member (2019 – 2024)

title: Drive’s Weather and Climate Hub 🌎✨
text: Welcome to my personal collection of the most exciting weather and climate resources! Whether I’m tracking storms, digging into historical data, or exploring climate models, these tools are always at my fingertips. 🌤️ Dive in and enjoy this weather nerd’s dream hub! 🌪️

title: Drive’s Weather and Climate Hub 🌎✨
text:
🌬️ Tracking Weather in Real-Time

🛰️ Windy: Stunning interactive maps for wind, temperature, rain, and more. Perfect for storm chasers or just checking today’s weather. 🌪️
🌊 Tropical Tidbits: Your one-stop shop for tropical cyclone updates, forecasts, and deep analysis.
🌐 Earth Nullschool: A live visualization of global weather patterns. Watch wind, ocean currents, and even CO2 flow across the planet—it’s mesmerizing. 💨

title: Drive’s Weather and Climate Hub 🌎✨
text:
📊 Digging into Climate Data

🧭 Climate Prediction Center: Seasonal outlooks, ENSO updates, and insights into long-term climate patterns. Stay ahead of what’s coming. 📅
🗂️ National Centers for Environmental Information: A goldmine of historical climate data for quick global or regional analysis.
🌈 Climate Reanalyzer: Gorgeous maps and graphs for current weather and historical climate data.

title: Drive’s Weather and Climate Hub 🌎✨
text:
🔬 Exploring Climate Models

🌐 World Climate Research Programme: Global collaborations to improve our understanding of Earth’s climate system.
🌋 CESM2 Single Forcing Large Ensemble Project: Disentangling the effects of greenhouse gases, aerosols, and natural forcings.
🧪 CESM2 Large Ensemble Community Project (LENS2): Dive into climate variability and human-induced changes through state-of-the-art models.
📈 Coupled Model Intercomparison Project 6 (CMIP6): A treasure trove of climate model experiments shaping the future of climate science.

title: Drive’s Weather and Climate Hub 🌎✨
text:
🛠️ Tools for Custom Insights

📊 MeteoBlue Climate Diagram Generator: Generate climate diagrams for anywhere on Earth in just a few clicks. Super handy for research or just satisfying curiosity. 🌍
🔍 NOAA Physical Sciences Laboratory: Explore datasets, tools, and analyses to help uncover the secrets of our atmosphere. 🌤️
📈 Climate Data Guide: A wealth of resources for understanding and working with climate data. From tutorials to datasets, it’s a must-visit for climate enthusiasts. 📚


🌟 This hub reflects my passion for understanding weather and climate systems. 🌎 Whether it’s tracking a hurricane or diving into the nuances of climate projections, these tools fuel my curiosity and help me connect the dots. 🌈 Let’s keep exploring the wonders of our incredible planet. 🌤️💡

title: 3D Terrain Visualization with Rayshader
text: This blog showcases 3D visualizations of four of the most mountainous regions in the world. Using rayshader, we render terrain data into stunning 3D plots.

title: 3D Terrain Visualization with Rayshader
text:
Libraries and Setup


Code
library(rayshader)
library(elevatr)
library(sf)
library(terra)

title: 3D Terrain Visualization with Rayshader
text:
Render 3D Terrain Plots


Code
render_terrain <- function(lon_min, lon_max, lat_min, lat_max, output_file = "terrain_render.png") {
  # Create bounding box
  bbox <- st_as_sf(
    data.frame(x = c(lon_min, lon_max), y = c(lat_min, lat_max)),
    coords = c("x", "y"), crs = 4326
  )
  
  # Retrieve elevation data
  elevation <- get_elev_raster(locations = bbox, z = 10, clip = "bbox")
  elevation_matrix <- as.matrix(elevation)
  
  # Handle missing values
  elevation_matrix[is.na(elevation_matrix)] <- 0
  
  # Apply shading and render
  elevation_matrix %>%
    sphere_shade(texture = "imhof1") %>%
    plot_3d(elevation_matrix, zscale = 50, theta = -45, phi = 45, windowsize = c(1000, 800))
  
  # Render high-quality image
  render_highquality(filename = output_file, samples = 200, light = TRUE)
  
  # Display the image in the Quarto document
  knitr::include_graphics(output_file)
}



1. Mount Shasta (North America)


Code
render_terrain(
  lon_min = -122.3, lon_max = -122.1,
  lat_min = 41.3, lat_max = 41.5,
  output_file = "mount_shasta_render.png"
)











2. Andes (South America)


Code
render_terrain(
  lon_min = -72.5, lon_max = -72.3,
  lat_min = -13.2, lat_max = -13.0,
  output_file = "andes_render.png"
)











3. Mount Kilimanjaro (Africa)


Code
render_terrain(
  lon_min = 37.3, lon_max = 37.5,
  lat_min = -3.1, lat_max = -2.9,
  output_file = "kilimanjaro_render.png"
)











4. Himalayas (Asia)


Code
render_terrain(
  lon_min = 86.8, lon_max = 87.0,
  lat_min = 27.8, lat_max = 28.0,
  output_file = "himalayas_render.png"
)

title: Home
text:
My name is Drive or Terachet Rojrachsombat (born February 11, 2000). I am currently pursuing a Master of Science in Earth Systems at Stanford University, I specialize in Climatology and Meteorology, with a focus on unraveling the complex interactions within Climate Change, aiming to be a professor one day.



Born and raised in Bangkok, Thailand, I developed an early passion for geography and philosophy. This dual interest led me to excel in both fields, earning gold medals at the International Geography Olympiad and Thailand Philosophy Olympiad. These formative experiences sparked a lifelong curiosity about the world and a commitment to addressing global environmental challenges.
At Stanford University, I transitioned from climate activism to scientific research, where I’ve contributed to projects ranging from monsoon dynamics to carbon chemistry in the Pacific Ocean. My Master’s thesis explores how aerosols influence global monsoon systems, with implications for future climate adaptation strategies.
Beyond research, I am passionate about teaching and mentoring. As a teaching assistant and peer advisor, I’ve guided students in courses on atmospheric dynamics and Earth systems science. I also remain committed to public outreach, translating complex scientific concepts into engaging lessons for diverse audiences.





Research Focus: Climate modeling, monsoon dynamics, and aerosol-cloud interactions.

Philosophical Insight: Integrating environmental ethics into scientific research.

Teaching Excellence: Inspiring the next generation of environmental scientists.

Personal Passions: Outdoor exploration, marine science, music, and history.






About Me: Learn more about my academic journey, research, and achievements.

Rayshader Blog: Explore my experiments with geospatial data and visualization.

Favorite Links: Check out my favorite resources and websites for science and inspiration.
